security_audit.summary: All 14 static findings are false positives. Network URL is legitimate GitHub source metadata. C2 keyword detections are schema enum values. Weak crypto detections are misinterpreted text. External command detection is DOT diagram syntax, not shell execution. This is a safe workflow governance skill with no malicious patterns.

content.user_title: Use Skills First for Disciplined AI Workflows
content.value_statement: AI assistants often skip established skill workflows when responding to user requests. This skill enforces a mandatory check for applicable skills before any response, ensuring consistent quality and proper tool usage across all conversations.
actual_capabilities: Enforces skill check before every response including clarifying questions
Provides a decision flowchart for determining skill applicability
Identifies rationalization patterns that indicate skipped skill checks
Establishes priority ordering for multiple applicable skills
Distinguishes between rigid and flexible skill types
limitations: Does not include built-in skill library or skill discovery mechanism
Cannot modify or create new skills within a conversation
Does not integrate with external task management systems
Enforcement depends on explicit skill activation, not automatic application

use_cases.title: New Conversation Setup
use_cases.description: Use at the start of any new conversation to establish skill-first workflow. Ensures all subsequent responses follow proper skill invocation procedures.

use_cases.title: Complex Task Management
use_cases.description: Apply when facing multi-step tasks requiring different approaches. Enforces process skills before implementation skills for better outcomes.

use_cases.title: Workflow Discipline Training
use_cases.description: Use during onboarding or when team members need reminders about proper skill usage. Reinforces systematic approach over ad-hoc responses.

prompt_templates.title: New Task Start
prompt_templates.prompt: Check for applicable skills for this task: [describe task]. If any skill might apply, invoke it first before responding.
prompt_templates.scenario: Starting work on a new user request

prompt_templates.title: Multiple Skills Potential
prompt_templates.prompt: Multiple skills could apply to this situation. Use the skill priority order: process skills first (brainstorming, debugging), then implementation skills. Invoke the appropriate skill.

prompt_templates.title: Self-Check for Rationalization
prompt_templates.prompt: Am I about to skip the skill check? Check if I am thinking: 'This is just a simple question', 'I need more context first', or 'I can check files quickly'. Stop and invoke applicable skills.

prompt_templates.title: Clarification Request
prompt_templates.prompt: Before asking clarifying questions, check if any skill provides guidance on what information to gather. Invoke that skill first.

output_examples.input: Fix the bug in user authentication
output: Using debugging skill to systematically diagnose the authentication issue
The debugging skill specifies: reproduce the issue, isolate the cause, fix the root cause, verify the fix

output_examples.input: Build a new REST API for user management
output: Using brainstorming skill first to plan the API design approach
After brainstorming: using mcp-builder skill to implement the API
Using code-reading skill to analyze the codebase structure
The code-reading skill provides a systematic approach to understanding unfamiliar code

best_practices: Always invoke the Skill tool even when you think the task is simple
Follow process skills (brainstorming, debugging) before implementation skills
Use the red flag checklist to catch rationalization patterns that lead to skipped skill checks
anti_patterns: Skipping skill check because 'this is just a quick question'
Starting implementation before process skills determine the approach
Assuming you remember a skill without reading the current version

faq.question: What if no skill applies to my task?
faq.answer: If after checking you determine no skill applies, you may respond directly. The skill explicitly says 'definitely not' applies.

faq.question: How do I know if a skill might apply?
faq.answer: The skill rule is clear: if there is even a 1% chance a skill applies, you must invoke it. This prevents rationalizing away proper workflow.

faq.question: Can I skip skills I have used many times before?
faq.answer: No. Skills evolve over time. Always read the current version. The skill explicitly warns against 'I remember this skill' thinking.

faq.question: What about clarifying questions?
faq.answer: Skill checks come BEFORE clarifying questions. If a skill tells you how to gather information, follow that process first.

faq.question: How do I handle multiple applicable skills?
faq.answer: Use priority order: process skills (brainstorming, debugging) first, then implementation skills. The skill provides specific guidance.

faq.question: Does this skill work with all Claude tools?
faq.answer: Yes. This skill is compatible with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code. The enforcement applies regardless of which tool you use.
